newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: Contributions to pension schemes rising - NZ's LOA.
newsitem.headline: Contributions to pension schemes rising - NZ's LOA.

text.p: Regular contributions into superannuation schemes rose by around 20 percent in the September year, The Life Office Association said on Tuesday.
Releasing its 1996 Statistical Review, the LOA said single premiums or lump sum contributions for superannuation were up 60 percent for the September year, at NZ$284 million.
"Over $524 million per year is being invested into superannuation schemes managed by life offices," association chief executive Arthur Davis said.

He said a Reserve Bank of New Zealand survey showed life offices continued to be the dominant manager of superannuation funds, with more than $6.5 billion under management. Banks followed next with $3.8 billion.

Davis said there had been a dramatic increase of nearly 50 percent in the investment income of life offices in the June year, and a rise of 23 percent in the September year showed those levels were being sustained.
However, traditional life insurance business in force showed a slight reduction for the June year, which Davis said was in line with world wide trends.

In August this year the LOA announced it would join with the Investment Funds Association of New Zealand to form a new organisation, the Investment Savings and Insurance Association of New Zealand. The new association will represent the life insurance, superannuation and managed funds industry.
Davis said it was expected the new association would continue to collect statistics on life insurance activity to ensure the series was maintained.
